017/**
018 * Data that can be used to limit the colors present in a Pixmap or other image, here with the goal of using 256 or less
019 * colors in the image (for saving indexed-mode images).
020 * <br>
021 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 6/23/2018.
022 */
023public class PaletteReducer {
024    public final byte[] paletteMapping = new byte[0x8000];
025    public final int[] paletteArray = new int[256];
026    ByteArray curErrorRedBytes, nextErrorRedBytes, curErrorGreenBytes, nextErrorGreenBytes, curErrorBlueBytes, nextErrorBlueBytes;
027    float ditherStrength = 0.5f, halfDitherStrength = 0.25f;
028    /**
029     * DawnBringer's 256-color Aurora palette, modified slightly to fit one transparent color by removing one gray.
030     * Aurora is available in <a href="http://pixeljoint.com/forum/forum_posts.asp?TID=26080&KW=">this set of tools</a>
031     * for a pixel art editor, but it is usable for lots of high-color purposes.
032     */
033    public static final int[] auroraPalette = {
034            0x00000000, 0x010101FF, 0x131313FF, 0x252525FF, 0x373737FF, 0x494949FF, 0x5B5B5BFF, 0x6E6E6EFF,

068    /**
069     * Constructs a default PaletteReducer that uses the DawnBringer Aurora palette.
070     */
071    public PaletteReducer() {
072        exact(auroraPalette);
073    }
074
075    /**
076     * Constructs a PaletteReducer that uses the given array of RGBA8888 ints as a palette (see {@link #exact(int[])}
077     * for more info).
078     *
079     * @param rgbaPalette an array of RGBA8888 ints to use as a palette
080     */
081    public PaletteReducer(int[] rgbaPalette) {
082        exact(rgbaPalette);
083    }
084
085    /**
086     * Constructs a PaletteReducer that uses the given array of Color objects as a palette (see {@link #exact(Color[])}
087     * for more info).
088     *
089     * @param colorPalette an array of Color objects to use as a palette
090     */
091    public PaletteReducer(Color[] colorPalette) {
092        exact(colorPalette);
093    }
094
095    /**
096     * Constructs a PaletteReducer that uses the given Array of Color objects as a palette (see {@link #exact(Color[])}
097     * for more info).
098     *
099     * @param colorPalette an array of Color objects to use as a palette
100     */
101    public PaletteReducer(Array<Color> colorPalette) {
102        if (colorPalette != null)
103            exact(colorPalette.items, colorPalette.size);
104        else
105            exact(auroraPalette);
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Constructs a PaletteReducer that analyzes the given Pixmap for color count and frequency to generate a palette
110     * (see {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} for more info).
111     *
112     * @param pixmap a Pixmap to analyze in detail to produce a palette
113     */
114    public PaletteReducer(Pixmap pixmap) {
115        analyze(pixmap);
116    }
117
118    /**
119     * Constructs a PaletteReducer that analyzes the given Pixmap for color count and frequency to generate a palette
120     * (see {@link #analyze(Pixmap, int)} for more info).
121     *
122     * @param pixmap    a Pixmap to analyze in detail to produce a palette
123     * @param threshold the minimum difference between colors required to put them in the palette (default 400)
124     */
125    public PaletteReducer(Pixmap pixmap, int threshold) {
126        analyze(pixmap, threshold);
127    }
128
129    /**
130     * Color difference metric; returns large numbers even for smallish differences.
131     * If this returns 250 or more, the colors may be perceptibly different; 500 or more almost guarantees it.
132     *
133     * @param color1 an RGBA8888 color as an int
134     * @param color2 an RGBA8888 color as an int
135     * @return the difference between the given colors, as a positive int
136     */
137    public static int difference(final int color1, final int color2) {
138        int rmean = ((color1 >>> 24) + (color2 >>> 24));
139        int r = (color1 >>> 24) - (color2 >>> 24);
140        int g = (color1 >>> 16 & 0xFF) - (color2 >>> 16 & 0xFF) << 1;
141        int b = (color1 >>> 8 & 0xFF) - (color2 >>> 8 & 0xFF);
142//        return (((512 + rmean) * r * r) >> 8) + g * g + (((767 - rmean) * b * b) >> 8);
143        return (((1024 + rmean) * r * r) >> 9) + g * g + (((767 - rmean) * b * b) >> 8);
144    }
145
146    /**
147     * Color difference metric; returns large numbers even for smallish differences.
148     * If this returns 250 or more, the colors may be perceptibly different; 500 or more almost guarantees it.
149     *
150     * @param color1 an RGBA8888 color as an int
151     * @param r2     red value from 0 to 255, inclusive
152     * @param g2     green value from 0 to 255, inclusive
153     * @param b2     blue value from 0 to 255, inclusive
154     * @return the difference between the given colors, as a positive int
155     */
156    public static int difference(final int color1, int r2, int g2, int b2) {
157//        r2 = (r2 << 3 | r2 >>> 2);
158//        g2 = (g2 << 3 | g2 >>> 2);
159//        b2 = (b2 << 3 | b2 >>> 2);
160        final int rmean = ((color1 >>> 24) + r2),
161                r = (color1 >>> 24) - r2,
162                g = (color1 >>> 16 & 0xFF) - g2 << 1,
163                b = (color1 >>> 8 & 0xFF) - b2;
164        return (((1024 + rmean) * r * r) >> 9) + g * g + (((767 - rmean) * b * b) >> 8);
165    }
166
167    /**
168     * Color difference metric; returns large numbers even for smallish differences.
169     * If this returns 250 or more, the colors may be perceptibly different; 500 or more almost guarantees it.
170     *
171     * @param r1 red value from 0 to 255, inclusive
172     * @param r2 red value from 0 to 255, inclusive
173     * @param g1 green value from 0 to 255, inclusive
174     * @param g2 green value from 0 to 255, inclusive
175     * @param b1 blue value from 0 to 255, inclusive
176     * @param b2 blue value from 0 to 255, inclusive
177     * @return the difference between the given colors, as a positive int
178     */
179    public static int difference(final int r1, final int r2, final int g1, final int g2, final int b1, final int b2) {
180        final int rmean = (r1 + r2),
181                r = r1 - r2,
182                g = g1 - g2 << 1,
183                b = b1 - b2;
184//        return (((512 + rmean) * r * r) >> 8) + g * g + (((767 - rmean) * b * b) >> 8);
185        return (((1024 + rmean) * r * r) >> 9) + g * g + (((767 - rmean) * b * b) >> 8);
186    }
187    private static int luma(final int r, final int g, final int b) {
188        return r * 0x9C + g * 0xF6 + b * 0x65 + 0x18 - (Math.max(r, Math.max(g, b)) - Math.min(r, Math.min(g, b))) * 0x19 >> 8;
189    }

238    /**
239     * Gets a pseudo-random float between -0.65625f and 0.65625f, determined by the upper 23 bits of seed.
240     * This currently uses a uniform distribution for its output, but earlier versions intentionally used a non-uniform
241     * one; a non-uniform distribution can sometimes work well but is very dependent on how error propagates through a
242     * dithered image, and in bad cases can produce bands of bright mistakenly-error-adjusted colors.
243     * @param seed any int, but only the most-significant 23 bits will be used
244     * @return a float between -0.65625f and 0.65625f, with fairly uniform distribution as long as seed is uniform
245     */
246    public static float randomXi(int seed)
247    {
248        return ((seed >> 9) * 0x1.5p-23f);
249//        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((seed & 0x7FFFFF & ((seed >>> 11 & 0x400000)|0x3FFFFF)) | 0x3f800000) - 1.4f;
250//        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((seed & 0x7FFFFF & ((seed >>> 11 & 0x600000)|0x1FFFFF)) | 0x3f800000) - 1.3f;
251    }
252
253    /**
254     * Builds the palette information this PNG8 stores from the RGBA8888 ints in {@code rgbaPalette}, up to 256 colors.
255     * Alpha is not preserved except for the first item in rgbaPalette, and only if it is {@code 0} (fully transparent
256     * black); otherwise all items are treated as opaque. If rgbaPalette is null, empty, or only has one color, then
257     * this defaults to DawnBringer's Aurora palette with 256 hand-chosen colors (including transparent).
258     *
259     * @param rgbaPalette an array of RGBA8888 ints; all will be used up to 256 items or the length of the array
260     */
261    public void exact(int[] rgbaPalette) {
262        if (rgbaPalette == null || rgbaPalette.length < 2) {
263            rgbaPalette = auroraPalette;
264        }
265        Arrays.fill(paletteArray, 0);
266        Arrays.fill(paletteMapping, (byte) 0);
267        final int plen = Math.min(256, rgbaPalette.length);
268        int color, c2;
269        int dist;
270        for (int i = 0; i < plen; i++) {
271            color = rgbaPalette[i];
272            paletteArray[i] = color;
273            paletteMapping[(color >>> 17 & 0x7C00) | (color >>> 14 & 0x3E0) | (color >>> 11 & 0x1F)] = (byte) i;
274        }
275        int rr, gg, bb;
276        for (int r = 0; r < 32; r++) {
277            rr = (r << 3 | r >>> 2);
278            for (int g = 0; g < 32; g++) {
279                gg = (g << 3 | g >>> 2);
280                for (int b = 0; b < 32; b++) {
281                    c2 = r << 10 | g << 5 | b;
282                    if (paletteMapping[c2] == 0) {
283                        bb = (b << 3 | b >>> 2);
284                        dist = 0x7FFFFFFF;
285                        for (int i = 1; i < plen; i++) {
286                            if (dist > (dist = Math.min(dist, difference(paletteArray[i], rr, gg, bb))))
287                                paletteMapping[c2] = (byte) i;
288                        }
289                    }
290                }
291            }
292        }
293    }
294
295    /**
296     * Builds the palette information this PNG8 stores from the Color objects in {@code colorPalette}, up to 256 colors.
297     * Alpha is not preserved except for the first item in colorPalette, and only if its r, g, b, and a values are all
298     * 0f (fully transparent black); otherwise all items are treated as opaque. If rgbaPalette is null, empty, or only
299     * has one color, then this defaults to DawnBringer's Aurora palette with 256 hand-chosen colors (including
300     * transparent).
301     *
302     * @param colorPalette an array of Color objects; all will be used up to 256 items or the length of the array
303     */
304    public void exact(Color[] colorPalette) {
305        exact(colorPalette, 256);
306    }
307
308    /**
309     * Builds the palette information this PNG8 stores from the Color objects in {@code colorPalette}, up to 256 colors.
310     * Alpha is not preserved except for the first item in colorPalette, and only if its r, g, b, and a values are all
311     * 0f (fully transparent black); otherwise all items are treated as opaque. If rgbaPalette is null, empty, only has
312     * one color, or limit is less than 2, then this defaults to DawnBringer's Aurora palette with 256 hand-chosen
313     * colors (including transparent).
314     *
315     * @param colorPalette an array of Color objects; all will be used up to 256 items, limit, or the length of the array
316     * @param limit        a limit on how many Color items to use from colorPalette; useful if colorPalette is from an Array
317     */
318    public void exact(Color[] colorPalette, int limit) {
319        if (colorPalette == null || colorPalette.length < 2 || limit < 2) {
320            exact(auroraPalette);
321            return;
322        }
323        Arrays.fill(paletteArray, 0);
324        Arrays.fill(paletteMapping, (byte) 0);
325        final int plen = Math.min(Math.min(256, colorPalette.length), limit);
326        int color, c2;
327        int dist;
328        for (int i = 0; i < plen; i++) {
329            color = Color.rgba8888(colorPalette[i]);
330            paletteArray[i] = color;
331            paletteMapping[(color >>> 17 & 0x7C00) | (color >>> 14 & 0x3E0) | (color >>> 11 & 0x1F)] = (byte) i;
332        }
333        int rr, gg, bb;
334        for (int r = 0; r < 32; r++) {
335            rr = (r << 3 | r >>> 2);
336            for (int g = 0; g < 32; g++) {
337                gg = (g << 3 | g >>> 2);
338                for (int b = 0; b < 32; b++) {
339                    c2 = r << 10 | g << 5 | b;
340                    if (paletteMapping[c2] == 0) {
341                        bb = (b << 3 | b >>> 2);
342                        dist = 0x7FFFFFFF;
343                        for (int i = 1; i < plen; i++) {
344                            if (dist > (dist = Math.min(dist, difference(paletteArray[i], rr, gg, bb))))
345                                paletteMapping[c2] = (byte) i;
346                        }
347                    }
348                }
349            }
350        }
351    }
352    /**
353     * Analyzes {@code pixmap} for color count and frequency, building a palette with at most 256 colors if there are
354     * too many colors to store in a PNG-8 palette. If there are 256 or less colors, this uses the exact colors
355     * (although with at most one transparent color, and no alpha for other colors); if there are more than 256 colors
356     * or any colors have 50% or less alpha, it will reserve a palette entry for transparent (even if the image has no
357     * transparency). Because calling {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} (or any of PNG8's write methods) will dither colors that
358     * aren't exact, and dithering works better when the palette can choose colors that are sufficiently different, this
359     * uses a threshold value to determine whether it should permit a less-common color into the palette, and if the
360     * second color is different enough (as measured by {@link #difference(int, int)}) by a value of at least 400, it is
361     * allowed in the palette, otherwise it is kept out for being too similar to existing colors. This doesn't return a
362     * value but instead stores the palette info in this object; a PaletteReducer can be assigned to the
363     * {@link PNG8#palette} field or can be used directly to {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} a Pixmap.
364     *
365     * @param pixmap a Pixmap to analyze, making a palette which can be used by this to {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} or by PNG8
366     */
367    public void analyze(Pixmap pixmap) {
368        analyze(pixmap, 400);
369    }
370
371    private static final Comparator<IntIntMap.Entry> entryComparator = new Comparator<IntIntMap.Entry>() {
372        @Override
373        public int compare(IntIntMap.Entry o1, IntIntMap.Entry o2) {
374            return o2.value - o1.value;
375        }
376    };
377
378
379    /**
380     * Analyzes {@code pixmap} for color count and frequency, building a palette with at most 256 colors if there are
381     * too many colors to store in a PNG-8 palette. If there are 256 or less colors, this uses the exact colors
382     * (although with at most one transparent color, and no alpha for other colors); if there are more than 256 colors
383     * or any colors have 50% or less alpha, it will reserve a palette entry for transparent (even if the image has no
384     * transparency). Because calling {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} (or any of PNG8's write methods) will dither colors that
385     * aren't exact, and dithering works better when the palette can choose colors that are sufficiently different, this
386     * takes a threshold value to determine whether it should permit a less-common color into the palette, and if the
387     * second color is different enough (as measured by {@link #difference(int, int)}) by a value of at least
388     * {@code threshold}, it is allowed in the palette, otherwise it is kept out for being too similar to existing
389     * colors. The threshold is usually between 250 and 1000, and 400 is a good default. This doesn't return a value but
390     * instead stores the palette info in this object; a PaletteReducer can be assigned to the {@link PNG8#palette}
391     * field or can be used directly to {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} a Pixmap.
392     *
393     * @param pixmap    a Pixmap to analyze, making a palette which can be used by this to {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} or by PNG8
394     * @param threshold a minimum color difference as produced by {@link #difference(int, int)}; usually between 250 and 1000, 400 is a good default
395     */
396    public void analyze(Pixmap pixmap, int threshold) {
397        Arrays.fill(paletteArray, 0);
398        Arrays.fill(paletteMapping, (byte) 0);
399        int color;
400        final int width = pixmap.getWidth(), height = pixmap.getHeight();
401        IntIntMap counts = new IntIntMap(256);
402        int hasTransparent = 0;
403        int[] reds = new int[256], greens = new int[256], blues = new int[256];
404        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
405            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
406                color = pixmap.getPixel(x, y);
407                if ((color & 0x80) != 0) {
408                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
409                    counts.getAndIncrement(color, 0, 1);
410                } else {
411                    hasTransparent = 1;
412                }
413            }
414        }
415        final int cs = counts.size;
416        if (cs + hasTransparent <= 256) {
417            int i = hasTransparent;
418            for(IntIntMap.Entry e : counts) {
419                color = e.key;
420                paletteArray[i] = color;
421                color = (color >>> 17 & 0x7C00) | (color >>> 14 & 0x3E0) | (color >>> 11 & 0x1F);
422                paletteMapping[color] = (byte) i;
423                reds[i] = color >>> 10;
424                greens[i] = color >>> 5 & 31;
425                blues[i] = color & 31;
426                i++;
427            }
428        } else // reduce color count
429        {
430            ArrayList<IntIntMap.Entry> es = new ArrayList<>(cs);
431            for(IntIntMap.Entry e : counts)
432            {
433                IntIntMap.Entry e2 = new IntIntMap.Entry();
434                e2.key = e.key;
435                e2.value = e.value;
436                es.add(e2);
437            }
438            Collections.sort(es, entryComparator);
439            int i = 1, c = 0;
440            PER_BEST:
441            for (; i < 256 && c < cs;) {
442                color = es.get(c++).key;
443                for (int j = 1; j < i; j++) {
444                    if (difference(color, paletteArray[j]) < threshold)
445                        continue PER_BEST;
446                }
447                paletteArray[i] = color;
448                color = (color >>> 17 & 0x7C00) | (color >>> 14 & 0x3E0) | (color >>> 11 & 0x1F);
449                paletteMapping[color] = (byte) i;
450                reds[i] = color >>> 10;
451                greens[i] = color >>> 5 & 31;
452                blues[i] = color & 31;
453                i++;
454            }
455        }
456        int c2, dist;
457        for (int r = 0; r < 32; r++) {
458            for (int g = 0; g < 32; g++) {
459                for (int b = 0; b < 32; b++) {
460                    c2 = r << 10 | g << 5 | b;
461                    if (paletteMapping[c2] == 0) {
462                        dist = 0x7FFFFFFF;
463                        for (int i = 1; i < 256; i++) {
464                            if (dist > (dist = Math.min(dist, difference(reds[i], r, greens[i], g, blues[i], b))))
465                                paletteMapping[c2] = (byte) i;
466                        }
467                    }
468                }
469            }
470        }
471    }
472
473    /**
474     * Changes the "strength" of the dither effect applied during {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} calls. The default is 1f,
475     * and while both values higher than 1f and lower than 1f are valid, they should not be negative. If you want dither
476     * to be eliminated, don't set dither strength to 0; use {@link #reduceSolid(Pixmap)} instead of reduce().
477     * @param ditherStrength dither strength as a non-negative float that should be close to 1f
478     */
479    public void setDitherStrength(float ditherStrength) {
480        this.ditherStrength = 0.5f * ditherStrength;
481        this.halfDitherStrength = 0.25f * ditherStrength;
482    }
483    public Pixmap reduce (Pixmap pixmap) {
484        return reduceFloydSteinberg(pixmap);
485    }
486    /**
487     * Modifies the given Pixmap so it only uses colors present in this PaletteReducer, dithering when it can.
488     * The dithering algorithm here is based on
489     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences">one suggested by
490     * Martin Roberts</a> using a generalization of the golden ratio, using the quasi-random value per pixel to get a
491     * multiplier for all channels (instead of a threshold for choosing just black or white). This adds noise but tends
492     * to look better than most other approaches, and is an ordered dither with all the various advantages that offers.
493     * If you want to reduce the colors in a Pixmap based on what it currently contains, call
494     * {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} with {@code pixmap} as its argument, then call this method with the same
495     * Pixmap. You may instead want to use a known palette instead of one computed from a Pixmap;
496     * {@link #exact(int[])} is the tool for that job. If you can compute the PaletteReducer once and reuse it, that
497     * will save some time on repeated calls to reduce(). <a href="https://imgur.com/a/wfdYtJn">A gallery of different
498     * dithering techniques is here</a>; this method is last.
499     * @param pixmap a Pixmap that will be modified in place
500     * @return the given Pixmap, for chaining
501     */
502    public Pixmap reduceRoberts (Pixmap pixmap) {
503        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
504        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
505        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
506        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
507        int color, used;
508        float adj;
509        byte paletteIndex;
510        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
511            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
512                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y) & 0xF8F8F880;
513                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
514                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
515                else {
516                    adj = (((px * 0xC13FA9A902A6328FL + y * 0x91E10DA5C79E7B1DL >>> 40) * 0x1p-26f - 0x1p-3f) * ditherStrength);
517                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
518                    int rr = MathUtils.clamp((int) (((color >>> 24)       ) * (1f + adj)), 0, 0xFF);
519                    int gg = MathUtils.clamp((int) (((color >>> 16) & 0xFF) * (1f + adj)), 0, 0xFF);
520                    int bb = MathUtils.clamp((int) (((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF) * (1f + adj)), 0, 0xFF);
521                    paletteIndex =
522                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
523                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
524                                    | ((bb >>> 3))];
525                    used = paletteArray[paletteIndex & 0xFF];
526                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, used);
527                }
528            }
529        }
530        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
531        return pixmap;
532    }
533    public Pixmap reduceSierraLite (Pixmap pixmap) {
534        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
535        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
536        byte[] curErrorRed, nextErrorRed, curErrorGreen, nextErrorGreen, curErrorBlue, nextErrorBlue;
537        if (curErrorRedBytes == null) {
538            curErrorRed = (curErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
539            nextErrorRed = (nextErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
540            curErrorGreen = (curErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
541            nextErrorGreen = (nextErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
542            curErrorBlue = (curErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
543            nextErrorBlue = (nextErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
544        } else {
545            curErrorRed = curErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
546            nextErrorRed = nextErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
547            curErrorGreen = curErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
548            nextErrorGreen = nextErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
549            curErrorBlue = curErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
550            nextErrorBlue = nextErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
551            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
552                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
553                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
554                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
555            }
556
557        }
558        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
559        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
560        int color, used, rdiff, gdiff, bdiff;
561        byte er, eg, eb, paletteIndex;
562        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
563            int ny = y + 1;
564            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
565                curErrorRed[i] = nextErrorRed[i];
566                curErrorGreen[i] = nextErrorGreen[i];
567                curErrorBlue[i] = nextErrorBlue[i];
568                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
569                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
570                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
571            }
572            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
573                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y) & 0xF8F8F880;
574                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
575                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
576                else {
577                    er = curErrorRed[px];
578                    eg = curErrorGreen[px];
579                    eb = curErrorBlue[px];
580                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
581                    int rr = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 24)       ) + (er), 0, 0xFF);
582                    int gg = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 16) & 0xFF) + (eg), 0, 0xFF);
583                    int bb = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF) + (eb), 0, 0xFF);
584                    paletteIndex =
585                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
586                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
587                                    | ((bb >>> 3))];
588                    used = paletteArray[paletteIndex & 0xFF];
589                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, used);
590                    rdiff = (color>>>24)-    (used>>>24);
591                    gdiff = (color>>>16&255)-(used>>>16&255);
592                    bdiff = (color>>>8&255)- (used>>>8&255);
593                    if(px < lineLen - 1)
594                    {
595                        curErrorRed[px+1]   += rdiff * ditherStrength;
596                        curErrorGreen[px+1] += gdiff * ditherStrength;
597                        curErrorBlue[px+1]  += bdiff * ditherStrength;
598                    }
599                    if(ny < h)
600                    {
601                        if(px > 0)
602                        {
603                            nextErrorRed[px-1]   += rdiff * halfDitherStrength;
604                            nextErrorGreen[px-1] += gdiff * halfDitherStrength;
605                            nextErrorBlue[px-1]  += bdiff * halfDitherStrength;
606                        }
607                        nextErrorRed[px]   += rdiff * halfDitherStrength;
608                        nextErrorGreen[px] += gdiff * halfDitherStrength;
609                        nextErrorBlue[px]  += bdiff * halfDitherStrength;
610                    }
611                }
612            }
613
614        }
615        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
616        return pixmap;
617    }
618
619    /**
620     * Modifies the given Pixmap so it only uses colors present in this PaletteReducer, without dithering. This produces
621     * blocky solid sections of color in most images where the palette isn't exact, instead of checkerboard-like
622     * dithering patterns. If you want to reduce the colors in a Pixmap based on what it currently contains, call
623     * {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} with {@code pixmap} as its argument, then call this method with the same
624     * Pixmap. You may instead want to use a known palette instead of one computed from a Pixmap;
625     * {@link #exact(int[])} is the tool for that job.
626     * @param pixmap a Pixmap that will be modified in place
627     * @return the given Pixmap, for chaining
628     */
629    public Pixmap reduceSolid (Pixmap pixmap) {
630        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
631        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
632        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
633        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
634        int color;
635        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
636            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
637                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y);
638                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
639                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
640                else {
641                    int rr = ((color >>> 24)       );
642                    int gg = ((color >>> 16) & 0xFF);
643                    int bb = ((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF);
644                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, paletteArray[
645                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
646                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
647                                    | ((bb >>> 3))] & 0xFF]);
648                }
649            }
650
651        }
652        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
653        return pixmap;
654    }
655
656    /**
657     * Modifies the given Pixmap so it only uses colors present in this PaletteReducer, dithering when it can using
658     * Burkes dithering instead of the Sierra Lite dithering that {@link #reduce(Pixmap)} uses.
659     * If you want to reduce the colors in a Pixmap based on what it currently contains, call
660     * {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} with {@code pixmap} as its argument, then call this method with the same
661     * Pixmap. You may instead want to use a known palette instead of one computed from a Pixmap;
662     * {@link #exact(int[])} is the tool for that job.
663     * <br>
664     * This method is not incredibly fast because of the extra calculations it has to do for dithering, but if you can
665     * compute the PaletteReducer once and reuse it, that will save some time. Burkes dithering causes error to be
666     * propagated to more than twice as many pixels as Sierra Lite (7 instead of 3), but both only affect one row ahead
667     * of the pixel that is currently being dithered. For small images, the time spent dithering should be negligible.
668     * @param pixmap a Pixmap that will be modified in place
669     * @return the given Pixmap, for chaining
670     */
671    public Pixmap reduceBurkes (Pixmap pixmap) {
672        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
673        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
674        float r4, r2, r1, g4, g2, g1, b4, b2, b1;
675        byte[] curErrorRed, nextErrorRed, curErrorGreen, nextErrorGreen, curErrorBlue, nextErrorBlue;
676        if (curErrorRedBytes == null) {
677            curErrorRed = (curErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
678            nextErrorRed = (nextErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
679            curErrorGreen = (curErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
680            nextErrorGreen = (nextErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
681            curErrorBlue = (curErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
682            nextErrorBlue = (nextErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
683        } else {
684            curErrorRed = curErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
685            nextErrorRed = nextErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
686            curErrorGreen = curErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
687            nextErrorGreen = nextErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
688            curErrorBlue = curErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
689            nextErrorBlue = nextErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
690            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
691                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
692                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
693                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
694            }
695
696        }
697        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
698        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
699        int color, used, rdiff, gdiff, bdiff;
700        byte er, eg, eb, paletteIndex;
701        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
702            int ny = y + 1;
703            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
704                curErrorRed[i] = nextErrorRed[i];
705                curErrorGreen[i] = nextErrorGreen[i];
706                curErrorBlue[i] = nextErrorBlue[i];
707                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
708                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
709                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
710            }
711            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
712                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y) & 0xF8F8F880;
713                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
714                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
715                else {
716                    er = curErrorRed[px];
717                    eg = curErrorGreen[px];
718                    eb = curErrorBlue[px];
719                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
720                    int rr = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 24)       ) + (er), 0, 0xFF);
721                    int gg = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 16) & 0xFF) + (eg), 0, 0xFF);
722                    int bb = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF) + (eb), 0, 0xFF);
723                    paletteIndex =
724                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
725                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
726                                    | ((bb >>> 3))];
727                    used = paletteArray[paletteIndex & 0xFF];
728                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, used);
729                    rdiff = (color>>>24)-    (used>>>24);
730                    gdiff = (color>>>16&255)-(used>>>16&255);
731                    bdiff = (color>>>8&255)- (used>>>8&255);
732                    r4 = rdiff * halfDitherStrength;
733                    g4 = gdiff * halfDitherStrength;
734                    b4 = bdiff * halfDitherStrength;
735                    r2 = r4 * 0.5f;
736                    g2 = g4 * 0.5f;
737                    b2 = b4 * 0.5f;
738                    r1 = r4 * 0.25f;
739                    g1 = g4 * 0.25f;
740                    b1 = b4 * 0.25f;
741                    if(px < lineLen - 1)
742                    {
743                        curErrorRed[px+1]   += r4;
744                        curErrorGreen[px+1] += g4;
745                        curErrorBlue[px+1]  += b4;
746                        if(px < lineLen - 2)
747                        {
748
749                            curErrorRed[px+2]   += r2;
750                            curErrorGreen[px+2] += g2;
751                            curErrorBlue[px+2]  += b2;
752                        }
753                    }
754                    if(ny < h)
755                    {
756                        if(px > 0)
757                        {
758                            nextErrorRed[px-1]   += r2;
759                            nextErrorGreen[px-1] += g2;
760                            nextErrorBlue[px-1]  += b2;
761                            if(px > 1)
762                            {
763                                nextErrorRed[px-2]   += r1;
764                                nextErrorGreen[px-2] += g1;
765                                nextErrorBlue[px-2]  += b1;
766                            }
767                        }
768                        nextErrorRed[px]   += r4;
769                        nextErrorGreen[px] += g4;
770                        nextErrorBlue[px]  += b4;
771                        if(px < lineLen - 1)
772                        {
773                            nextErrorRed[px+1]   += r2;
774                            nextErrorGreen[px+1] += g2;
775                            nextErrorBlue[px+1]  += b2;
776                            if(px < lineLen - 2)
777                            {
778
779                                nextErrorRed[px+2]   += r1;
780                                nextErrorGreen[px+2] += g1;
781                                nextErrorBlue[px+2]  += b1;
782                            }
783                        }
784                    }
785                }
786            }
787
788        }
789        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
790        return pixmap;
791    }
792
793    /**
794     * Modifies the given Pixmap so it only uses colors present in this PaletteReducer, dithering when it can using a
795     * modified version of the algorithm presented in "Simple gradient-based error-diffusion method" by Xaingyu Y. Hu in
796     * the Journal of Electronic Imaging, 2016. This algorithm uses pseudo-randomly-generated noise to adjust
797     * Floyd-Steinberg dithering, with input for the pseudo-random state obtained by the non-transparent color values as
798     * they are encountered. Very oddly, this tends to produce less random-seeming dither than
799     * {@link #reduceBurkes(Pixmap)}, with this method often returning regular checkerboards where Burkes may produce
800     * splotches of color. If you want to reduce the colors in a Pixmap based on what it currently contains, call
801     * {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} with {@code pixmap} as its argument, then call this method with the same
802     * Pixmap. You may instead want to use a known palette instead of one computed from a Pixmap;
803     * {@link #exact(int[])} is the tool for that job.
804     * <br>
805     * This method is not incredibly fast because of the extra calculations it has to do for dithering, but if you can
806     * compute the PaletteReducer once and reuse it, that will save some time. This method is probably slower than
807     * {@link #reduceBurkes(Pixmap)} even though Burkes propagates error to more pixels, because this method also has to
808     * generate two random values per non-transparent pixel. The random number "algorithm" this uses isn't very good
809     * because it doesn't have to be good, it should just be fast and avoid clear artifacts; it's similar to one of
810     * <a href="http://www.drdobbs.com/tools/fast-high-quality-parallel-random-number/231000484?pgno=2">Mark Overton's
811     * subcycle generators</a> (which are usually paired, but that isn't the case here), but because it's
812     * constantly being adjusted by additional colors as input, it may be more comparable to a rolling hash. This uses
813     * {@link #randomXi(int)} to get the parameter in Hu's paper that's marked as {@code aξ}, but our randomXi() is
814     * adjusted so it has half the range (from -0.5 to 0.5 instead of -1 to 1). That quirk ends up getting rather high
815     * quality for this method, though it may have some grainy appearance in certain zones with mid-level intensity (an
816     * acknowledged issue with the type of noise-based approach Hu uses, and not a very severe problem).
817     * @param pixmap a Pixmap that will be modified in place
818     * @return the given Pixmap, for chaining
819     */
820    public Pixmap reduceWithNoise (Pixmap pixmap) {
821        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
822        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
823        byte[] curErrorRed, nextErrorRed, curErrorGreen, nextErrorGreen, curErrorBlue, nextErrorBlue;
824        if (curErrorRedBytes == null) {
825            curErrorRed = (curErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
826            nextErrorRed = (nextErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
827            curErrorGreen = (curErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
828            nextErrorGreen = (nextErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
829            curErrorBlue = (curErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
830            nextErrorBlue = (nextErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
831        } else {
832            curErrorRed = curErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
833            nextErrorRed = nextErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
834            curErrorGreen = curErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
835            nextErrorGreen = nextErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
836            curErrorBlue = curErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
837            nextErrorBlue = nextErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
838            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
839                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
840                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
841                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
842            }
843
844        }
845        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
846        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
847        int color, used, rdiff, gdiff, bdiff, state = 0xFEEDBEEF;
848        byte er, eg, eb, paletteIndex;
849        //float xir1, xir2, xig1, xig2, xib1, xib2, // would be used if random factors were per-channel
850                // used now, where random factors are determined by whole colors as ints
851        float xi1, xi2, w1 = ditherStrength * 0.125f, w3 = w1 * 3f, w5 = w1 * 5f, w7 = w1 * 7f;
852        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
853            int ny = y + 1;
854            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
855                curErrorRed[i] = nextErrorRed[i];
856                curErrorGreen[i] = nextErrorGreen[i];
857                curErrorBlue[i] = nextErrorBlue[i];
858                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
859                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
860                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
861            }
862            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
863                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y) & 0xF8F8F880;
864                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
865                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
866                else {
867                    er = curErrorRed[px];
868                    eg = curErrorGreen[px];
869                    eb = curErrorBlue[px];
870                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
871                    int rr = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 24)       ) + (er), 0, 0xFF);
872                    int gg = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 16) & 0xFF) + (eg), 0, 0xFF);
873                    int bb = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF) + (eb), 0, 0xFF);
874                    paletteIndex =
875                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
876                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
877                                    | ((bb >>> 3))];
878                    used = paletteArray[paletteIndex & 0xFF];
879                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, used);
880                    rdiff = (color>>>24)-    (used>>>24);
881                    gdiff = (color>>>16&255)-(used>>>16&255);
882                    bdiff = (color>>>8&255)- (used>>>8&255);
883                    state += (color + 0x41C64E6D) ^ color >>> 7;
884                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
885                    xi1 = randomXi(state);
886                    state ^= (state << 15 | state >>> 17) + 0x9E3779B9;
887                    xi2 = randomXi(state);
888
889//                    state += rdiff ^ rdiff << 9;
890//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
891//                    xir1 = randomXi(state);
892//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
893//                    xir2 = randomXi(state);
894//                    state += gdiff ^ gdiff << 9;
895//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
896//                    xig1 = randomXi(state);
897//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
898//                    xig2 = randomXi(state);
899//                    state += bdiff ^ bdiff << 9;
900//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
901//                    xib1 = randomXi(state);
902//                    state = (state << 21 | state >>> 11);
903//                    xib2 = randomXi(state);
904                    if(px < lineLen - 1)
905                    {
906                        curErrorRed[px+1]   += rdiff * w7 * (1f + xi1);
907                        curErrorGreen[px+1] += gdiff * w7 * (1f + xi1);
908                        curErrorBlue[px+1]  += bdiff * w7 * (1f + xi1);
909                    }
910                    if(ny < h)
911                    {
912                        if(px > 0)
913                        {
914                            nextErrorRed[px-1]   += rdiff * w3 * (1f + xi2);
915                            nextErrorGreen[px-1] += gdiff * w3 * (1f + xi2);
916                            nextErrorBlue[px-1]  += bdiff * w3 * (1f + xi2);
917                        }
918                        if(px < lineLen - 1)
919                        {
920                            nextErrorRed[px+1]   += rdiff * w1 * (1f - xi2);
921                            nextErrorGreen[px+1] += gdiff * w1 * (1f - xi2);
922                            nextErrorBlue[px+1]  += bdiff * w1 * (1f - xi2);
923                        }
924                        nextErrorRed[px]   += rdiff * w5 * (1f - xi1);
925                        nextErrorGreen[px] += gdiff * w5 * (1f - xi1);
926                        nextErrorBlue[px]  += bdiff * w5 * (1f - xi1);
927                    }
928                }
929            }
930
931        }
932        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
933        return pixmap;
934    }
935
936    /**
937     * Modifies the given Pixmap so it only uses colors present in this PaletteReducer, dithering when it can using the
938     * commonly-used Floyd-Steinberg dithering. If you want to reduce the colors in a Pixmap based on what it currently
939     * contains, call {@link #analyze(Pixmap)} with {@code pixmap} as its argument, then call this method with the same
940     * Pixmap. You may instead want to use a known palette instead of one computed from a Pixmap;
941     * {@link #exact(int[])} is the tool for that job.
942     * <p>
943     * This method usually has the highest quality of the various dithering algorithms, and can be very similar to
944     * {@link #reduceWithNoise(Pixmap)} but tends to be less splotchy. It might not be incredibly fast because of the
945     * extra calculations it has to do for dithering, but if you can compute the PaletteReducer once and reuse it, that
946     * will save some time. This method is probably about the same speed as {@link #reduceBurkes(Pixmap)}.
947     * @param pixmap a Pixmap that will be modified in place
948     * @return the given Pixmap, for chaining
949     */
950    public Pixmap reduceFloydSteinberg (Pixmap pixmap) {
951        boolean hasTransparent = (paletteArray[0] == 0);
952        final int lineLen = pixmap.getWidth(), h = pixmap.getHeight();
953        byte[] curErrorRed, nextErrorRed, curErrorGreen, nextErrorGreen, curErrorBlue, nextErrorBlue;
954        if (curErrorRedBytes == null) {
955            curErrorRed = (curErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
956            nextErrorRed = (nextErrorRedBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
957            curErrorGreen = (curErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
958            nextErrorGreen = (nextErrorGreenBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
959            curErrorBlue = (curErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
960            nextErrorBlue = (nextErrorBlueBytes = new ByteArray(lineLen)).items;
961        } else {
962            curErrorRed = curErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
963            nextErrorRed = nextErrorRedBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
964            curErrorGreen = curErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
965            nextErrorGreen = nextErrorGreenBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
966            curErrorBlue = curErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
967            nextErrorBlue = nextErrorBlueBytes.ensureCapacity(lineLen);
968            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
969                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
970                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
971                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
972            }
973
974        }
975        Pixmap.Blending blending = pixmap.getBlending();
976        pixmap.setBlending(Pixmap.Blending.None);
977        int color, used, rdiff, gdiff, bdiff;
978        byte er, eg, eb, paletteIndex;
979        float w1 = ditherStrength * 0.125f, w3 = w1 * 3f, w5 = w1 * 5f, w7 = w1 * 7f;
980        for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
981            int ny = y + 1;
982            for (int i = 0; i < lineLen; i++) {
983                curErrorRed[i] = nextErrorRed[i];
984                curErrorGreen[i] = nextErrorGreen[i];
985                curErrorBlue[i] = nextErrorBlue[i];
986                nextErrorRed[i] = 0;
987                nextErrorGreen[i] = 0;
988                nextErrorBlue[i] = 0;
989            }
990            for (int px = 0; px < lineLen; px++) {
991                color = pixmap.getPixel(px, y) & 0xF8F8F880;
992                if ((color & 0x80) == 0 && hasTransparent)
993                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, 0);
994                else {
995                    er = curErrorRed[px];
996                    eg = curErrorGreen[px];
997                    eb = curErrorBlue[px];
998                    color |= (color >>> 5 & 0x07070700) | 0xFE;
999                    int rr = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 24)       ) + (er), 0, 0xFF);
1000                    int gg = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 16) & 0xFF) + (eg), 0, 0xFF);
1001                    int bb = MathUtils.clamp(((color >>> 8)  & 0xFF) + (eb), 0, 0xFF);
1002                    paletteIndex =
1003                            paletteMapping[((rr << 7) & 0x7C00)
1004                                    | ((gg << 2) & 0x3E0)
1005                                    | ((bb >>> 3))];
1006                    used = paletteArray[paletteIndex & 0xFF];
1007                    pixmap.drawPixel(px, y, used);
1008                    rdiff = (color>>>24)-    (used>>>24);
1009                    gdiff = (color>>>16&255)-(used>>>16&255);
1010                    bdiff = (color>>>8&255)- (used>>>8&255);
1011                    if(px < lineLen - 1)
1012                    {
1013                        curErrorRed[px+1]   += rdiff * w7;
1014                        curErrorGreen[px+1] += gdiff * w7;
1015                        curErrorBlue[px+1]  += bdiff * w7;
1016                    }
1017                    if(ny < h)
1018                    {
1019                        if(px > 0)
1020                        {
1021                            nextErrorRed[px-1]   += rdiff * w3;
1022                            nextErrorGreen[px-1] += gdiff * w3;
1023                            nextErrorBlue[px-1]  += bdiff * w3;
1024                        }
1025                        if(px < lineLen - 1)
1026                        {
1027                            nextErrorRed[px+1]   += rdiff * w1;
1028                            nextErrorGreen[px+1] += gdiff * w1;
1029                            nextErrorBlue[px+1]  += bdiff * w1;
1030                        }
1031                        nextErrorRed[px]   += rdiff * w5;
1032                        nextErrorGreen[px] += gdiff * w5;
1033                        nextErrorBlue[px]  += bdiff * w5;
1034                    }
1035                }
1036            }
1037        }
1038        pixmap.setBlending(blending);
1039        return pixmap;
1040    }
1041
1042    /**
1043     * Retrieves a random non-0 color index for the palette this would reduce to, with a higher likelihood for colors
1044     * that are used more often in reductions (those with few similar colors). The index is returned as a byte that,
1045     * when masked with 255 as with {@code (palette.randomColorIndex(random) & 255)}, can be used as an index into a
1046     * palette array with 256 or less elements that should have been used with {@link #exact(int[])} before to set the
1047     * palette this uses.
1048     * @param random an IRNG instance, such as a GWTRNG or RNG
1049     * @return a randomly selected color index from this palette with a non-uniform distribution, can be any byte but 0
1050     */
1051    public byte randomColorIndex(IRNG random)
1052    {
1053        return paletteMapping[random.next(15)];
1054    }
1055
1056    /**
1057     * Retrieves a random non-transparent color from the palette this would reduce to, with a higher likelihood for
1058     * colors that are used more often in reductions (those with few similar colors). The color is returned as an
1059     * RGBA8888 int; you can assign one of these into a Color with {@link Color#rgba8888ToColor(Color, int)} or
1060     * {@link Color#set(int)}.
1061     * @param random an IRNG instance, such as a GWTRNG or RNG
1062     * @return a randomly selected color from this palette with a non-uniform distribution
1063     */
1064    public int randomColor(IRNG random)
1065    {
1066        return paletteArray[paletteMapping[random.next(15)] & 255];
1067    }
1068
1069    /**
1070     * Looks up {@code color} as if it was part of an image being color-reduced and finds the closest color to it in the
1071     * palette this holds. Both the parameter and the returned color are RGBA8888 ints.
1072     * @param color an RGBA8888 int that represents a color this should try to find a similar color for in its palette
1073     * @return an RGBA8888 int representing a color from this palette, or 0 if color is mostly transparent
1074     * (0 is often but not always in the palette)
1075     */
1076    public int reduceSingle(int color)
1077    {
1078        if((color & 0x80) == 0) // less visible than half-transparent
1079            return 0; // transparent
1080        return paletteArray[paletteMapping[
1081                (color >>> 17 & 0x7C00) 
1082                        | (color >>> 14 & 0x3E0)
1083                        | (color >>> 11 & 0x1F)] & 0xFF];
1084    }
1085
1086    /**
1087     * Looks up {@code color} as if it was part of an image being color-reduced and finds the closest color to it in the
1088     * palette this holds. Both the parameter and the returned color are packed float colors, as produced by
1089     * {@link Color#toFloatBits()} or many methods in SColor.
1090     * @param packedColor a packed float color this should try to find a similar color for in its palette
1091     * @return a packed float color from this palette, or 0f if color is mostly transparent
1092     * (0f is often but not always in the palette)
1093     */
1094    public float reduceFloat(float packedColor)
1095    {
1096        final int color = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(packedColor); // color is ABGR8888
1097        if(color >= 0) // if color is non-negative, then alpha is less than half of opaque
1098            return 0f;
1099        return NumberTools.reversedIntBitsToFloat(paletteArray[paletteMapping[
1100                (color << 7 & 0x7C00)
1101                        | (color >>> 6 & 0x3E0)
1102                        | (color >>> 19 & 0x1F)] & 0xFF] & 0xFFFFFFFE);
1103        
1104    }
1105    
1106    /**
1107     * Modifies {@code color} so its RGB values will match the closest color in this PaletteReducer's palette. If color
1108     * has {@link Color#a} less than 0.5f, this will simply set color to be fully transparent, with rgba all 0.
1109     * @param color a libGDX Color that will be modified in-place; do not use a Color constant, use {@link Color#cpy()}
1110     *              or a temporary Color
1111     * @return color, after modifications.
1112     */
1113    public Color reduceInPlace(Color color)
1114    {
1115        if(color.a < 0.5f)
1116            return color.set(0);
1117        return color.set(paletteArray[paletteMapping[
1118                ((int) (color.r * 0x1f.8p+10) & 0x7C00)
1119                        | ((int) (color.g * 0x1f.8p+5) & 0x3E0)
1120                        | ((int) (color.r * 0x1f.8p+0))] & 0xFF]);
1121    }
1122
1123}
